description: The new debt relief law is stirring colonial resentment, as Puerto Rican officials denounced the “junta” — or federal control board — that will soon direct this island’s failing governance and finances.
title: How Puerto Rico Debt Is Grappling With a Debt Crisis
title_page: How Puerto Rico Debt Is Grappling With a Debt Crisis - The New York Times
maintext:
For years, Puerto Rico borrowed money by issuing municipal bonds, using the funds to compensate for declining government revenue and prevent deep cuts in services and layoffs of public workers. It easily found investors.
But Puerto Rico can no longer afford what it owes. The island is reeling under more than $70 billion of debt, and officials there have warned about its inability to pay back investors while maintaining essential services for residents such as health care and schools.
